resources.string: PREPARE
Test Anxiety Questionaire
Sub title
Prepare: a companion to manage exam stress
Find Out Support Nationwide
The services below offer a wide range of support if you need help for mental health issues.
Call 116 123 to talk to Samaritans, or email: jo@samaritans.org for a reply within 24 hours
If you just need to talk, any time of day or night
Text "SHOUT" to 85258 to contact the Shout Crisis Text Line, or text "YM" if you\'re under 19
BreatheActivity
First Fragment
Second Fragment
Next
Previous
Box breathing is a technique used in taking slow deep breaths\n \nThis can heighten performance and concentration whiles being a stress reliever.
If you need help urgently for your mental health, but it\'s not an emergency
Call 111 OR\n\nSpeak to your GP to advise you about helpful treatments and also help you access mental health services.
Student Mind
Student Mind the UK\'s student mental health charity.
You can access the services and support content they offer here
Student Nightline
You can speak to someone from your university about anything here
Nightline is a listening, emotional support, information and supplies service, run by students for students.
First: Create a weekly schedule. Write out a weekly schedule based on class time activities, free time and job activities
Second: Estimate the average amount needed for each subject to obtain a specific grade
Third: Schedule blocks of free time between subjects and assign them to study a particular subject
Fourth: Write down what you do whilst studying.Examples are breaks, nervousness.Note the length of time it takes to get started on the assignment
Monitoring of behaviour can lead to change
A research showed that University students obtaining higher grades reported the following about themselves:

ul.li: Although Students did not assign themselves a specific time to study each subject, they set aside a specific time to study everyday
They usually studied during the day between classes and made enjoyable activities upon completing a definite assignment
They studied a subject continuously for an hour rather than skipping between subjects
They began working on voluminous assignments long before the due date
They obtained 3–6 hours of exercise each week
They spent less time studying material specific to a subject than students receiving lower grades

resources.string:
SQ3R method is one of the effective ways of transferring reading materials into memory.\n
The process involves five steps : scan,question,read,recite and review.

Scan


Look over an entire chapter, attempt to gain a general understanding of what the author is saying.
 Look at major headings and relationships between them. Read the summary as it provides an overview of what the author thinks its important. 

You can take 5 minutes to complete this activity, picking 5-7 points which are important in the chapter

Question


What are you about to read? Transform major and minor headings into questions and write them into a notebook. This allows you to review chapters using a problem solving frame of reference. Areas of strengths and weakness could be be identified through this process when revising for an exam. 

The three types of questions which are important 

Definitions
 

Similarities and Differences
 

Examples

Read 


Read the chapter carefully now to find answers to questions you have written down. You can highlight the answers by the following options:
 

Using a personal notation system in the margin of the chapters to quickly find information when revising. Example I=Important, S=Summary VI=Very Important 


Writing the answers in a notebook under the questions.Use key phrases that will trigger recitation of concepts to avoid lengthy answers in notebook.
 
Focus on these major points when reading a specific chapter: 

The fist sentence of the paragraph. The rest of the lines usually explains the main point in the first line
 

Take note of graphs,table and charts, they summarize key concepts
 

Key Phrases which explain important information follow words like "firstly,secondly, thirdly and summary".

Recite\n
\nRecite answers to questions after reading a whole chapter. This produces a rapid method of learning from both verbal and auditory channel.

Review\n
\nReview material after answering all questions in the chapter. You should take less than 5 minutes to reanswer questions in the chapter from memory. A material that cannot be verbalised is not know.

ul.li: One hour lectures usually contains 3–6 main points

resources.string: This section is about lecture notes and preparing for exams, the following can be followed:

Lecturers may present materials in this manner:\n
Present overview of material that will be covered\n
State the main points and label them as important

Personal interest of examiner may appear in exams, be aware of them and the examiner's philosophy of testing
 

Terms such as "being able to apply what you have learnt" implies problem and analogy type questions in exams
 

"Knowing the basics" implies short answer and similarities and differences questions. 
 

The lecture itself will provide materials for an exam through handouts.

Always organise lecture notes after you write them down. Do the following after lectures: 

Take a few minutes to skim over notes
 

Write down sentences to summarize main points
 

Write down points you need clarification for the next lecture

Procedures that can help manage anxiety while preparing to take an exam:

Arrive early at the test centre
 

Bring the proper materials
 

Avoid discussions with others about possible questions and answers
 

If you cannot recall some material during the exam, try not to panic.
Click on the button below to begin creating your reminder!

You will be asked to rate how often you have been affected by a number of factor from \'not at all\' to \'always\'.\n \nThere are 10 questions and your total score shows your current level of test anxiety.

The assessment will take no more than five minutes.
You will also get a feedback based on what you score from the assessment

2.0 - 2.5 - Normal or average test anxiety 
Your score suggest a normal test anxiety level. "
This is only an indicator of how you are feeling at the moment" " 

Come back and re take this assessment if things change

2.5 - 2.9 - High normal test anxiety 
Your score suggests a mild test anxiety" " 

Your might find the tools in this app helpful in maintaining your well being

3.0 - 3.4 - Moderately high (some items rated 4=high) \nYour score suggest a moderately high test anxiety" " The symptoms may be interfering with your life and maybe causing some distress but may feel manageable" "\nThe tools in this app can help with some of the symptoms you are experiencing

3.5 - 3.9 - High test anxiety 
Your score suggest you have a high test anxiety, " "You may want to speak with your GP/Doctor or use a counselling service" "

If your symptoms are causing distress." "

The tools in the app provide some helpful tools to manage symptoms alongside treatment if you require it

4.0-5.0 -Extremely high anxiety , 
Your score suggests that you are experiencing high levels of test anxiety at the moment" + " We recommend booking an appointment with your GP or University Counselling services right away" "as there are many tools that could help you through this" "

 If you need to speak to someone urgently, you can speak to A&E department or" "talk to the Samaritans available 24/7(find them on the support page of the app
1.0 - 1.9 - Comfortably low test anxiety Your score suggests that you are not experiencing test anxiety at the moment
